Congratulations! You just debunked the antropogenic climate change theory or at the very least cast doubt on it. The CO2 release from soil as it thaws certainly makes the causation/correlation question a bit more murky. If scientists underestimate the rate of historic permafrost thaws, then some of the lag/lead assumptions on ice core date comes into question. With all due deference to a 90's kids television host, This is why climate change is not settled science.

So theoretically we might become a real life Schrodinger’s Cat:

In the future, we could be flourishing with plant life, or meeting our climate change demise.
Until that time, we are both.

Bacteria is not the only thing frozen in the permafrost. It's century old viruses that are surfacing in the melt too, like humans and animals that were frozen for centuries and have not decayed do to the lack of sunlight and oxygen (permafrost is so cold there's little or no oxygen). Now they are starting to surface in the melt and bring their diseases back with them as they thaw. I even read that some scientists are cautioning that even the bubonic plague could thaw out from centuries old mass graves that have been frozen over keeping the buried from full decomposition.

Kind of a foolish thought. Everywhere on the planet has bacteria in the soil. Any permafrost that melts will just end up doing to the atmosphere what any non frozen soil does right now. It will have bacteria, plants will grow, animals will move in, etc. It changes nothing.

Short of decreasing greenhouse gases... My recommendation would be to monitor permafrost extent and then to plant trees, or plants which can capture a lot of carbon quickly, and generate a lot of oxygen, wherever the permafrost melts. Probably the best way to do this would be to make it available for farming/plantations so that it becomes a commercially driven effort. Heck... Import the people who want to cut down rain forests in South America for farms to start farming there.

It is interesting and very true that this can become the case but what I think they tend to leave out is time. It took roughly 2 billion years for the cyanobacteria to alter the atmosphere into the habitable zone humans can breath and live in, thats a long time for something so small to make a global change like that to the atmosphere. Another point is that while yes it is true that the extra CO2 can be used for plants and in theory will indeed aid their growth, the problem is that from an ecological standpoint this is still a disaster. A disaster because this will lead to a nutrient explosion creating a lot more life and once that CO2 runs out what will continue to feed the growth left behind by the extra CO2? Nothing, and so it will burn through that extra nutrient and die off in massive massive amounts. And again, I would not expect to see either scenario expect to happen (by itself) for a couple hundred thousand years. The problem we have now though will most certainly be accelerated because humans are adding to all this with our own CO2 emissions.

Thawing permafrost caused an outbreak of anthrax in the very North of Russia a couple of months ago. Deceased deer that died from anthrax in the Middle Ages were buried deep beneath the permafrost, and the bacteria ascended to the surface, got into the ground waters and, well, infected Yakut nomads. Oh, and did I tell you that one of their traditions is eating raw meat? Several thousand deer died; witnesses say the decaying bodies of deer stink like hell, and the ill nomads complete the picture of a zombie apocalypse. People have been quarantined, placed in derelict hospitals and are fed anything but meat; they are disgusted by the vomit-inducing hospital ration but cannot do anything. The authorities did not intervene until the first death of a boy (!) who had drunk some raw deer blood despite the nomad camping grounds had been covered with dead deer for weeks.

For the sake of argument, let's grant that everybody on Earth agrees that climate change / global warming is 100% real, and tell scientists, in one unanimous voice, "We believe you!"

What would be the response?

Recycle more aluminum cans?

Transform every government, corporation and culture on the planet overnight to stave off nothing, because all the ill-effects of global warming are already inevitable?

We told you so?

And what are the ill-effects exactly?

Worse storms here and there, and more coastal flooding than ten years ago. Oh noo! how can we possibly adapt to that over the next five hundred years?!
